conclusion: Determine if the difference in displacement between objects A and B necessarily continuously increases over time from t=0 to t=t1.
Displacement can be found by calculating the area under the velocity-time graph.
Displacement d is calculated as the integral of velocity over time.
Difference in displacement Δd between objects A and B is the difference in their respective areas under the curve.
Both objects have positive velocity throughout the time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
At t=0, both objects start from rest with zero initial velocity.
Object A reaches a higher peak velocity than Object B before t1.
Since Object A has a higher maximum velocity, it will cover more distance than Object B initially.
As Object A starts decelerating, it will begin to lose ground to Object B because Object B's velocity continues to increase until t1.
Initially, Δd(t) will be positive, meaning Object A is ahead.
Once Object A's velocity decreases below Object B's, the difference in position will decrease, and Object A will fall behind Object B.
The difference in displacement does not necessarily continuously increase over the time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
Final answer: No, the difference in displacement does not necessarily continuously increase.
